body: Oh also, somehow nightly on PG passes even though the failure is at compile time not runtime. Because... yeah... reasons...

Not sure if you came across this in your searching, but apparently Travis CI provided a [workaround](https://launchpad.net/~travis-ci/+archive/ubuntu/sqlite3) for upgrading sqlite3, but unfortunately it only seems to work on their legacy infrastructure.

Actually, scratch that. I was able to get the build to pass by [manually installing](https://github.com/SoftwareWarlock/diesel/blob/diesel-sqlite-support/.travis.yml#L10) the workaround and setting the distro to [precise instead of trusty](https://github.com/SoftwareWarlock/diesel/blob/diesel-sqlite-support/.travis.yml#L2).

I'd prefer to avoid using apt-get for this if we can. Trusty _should_ ship
with 3.8 by default.

On Mon, Feb 1, 2016 at 11:24 AM Cameron Alexander notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Actually, scratch that. I was able to get the build to pass by manually
> installing the work around and setting the distro to precise instead of
> trusty
> https://github.com/SoftwareWarlock/diesel/blob/diesel-sqlite-support/.travis.yml#L2
> .
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/sgrif/diesel/issues/167#issuecomment-178109947.

issue.title: Fix failing build due to old sqlite3 version

repository.name: diesel
repository.description: A safe, extensible ORM and Query Builder for Rust

issue.body:
It seems that the original post in #167 was correct, the sqlite support branch was failing due to an ancient version of sqlite.

Tavis CI has provided a workaround for this, but it seems to only work on Ubuntu Precise. I haven't been able to tell for sure if this slows down the build, but it doesn't seem like it at the moment. One foreseeable issue is that this prevents moving to Travis' new container infrastructure, which offers features like caching.

Any thoughts on possible alternatives?

body:
Agreed. Maybe Travis is manually changing the version they have installed? I can't see a reason why the build would pass from manually upgrading sqlite if the installed default version really is 3.8.

Would you be willing to consider switching to a different CI system? I've had a pretty pleasant experience using CircleCI.
Just did a sanity check, and the version really is 3.8, so maybe the codegen is compatible with 3.7.15, but not 3.7.9 nor 3.8?

It's definitely compatible with 3.8. If you look at the failure message
appearing on Travis, it's due to `sqlite3_errstr` not being found, which
means it's an ancient 3.7 version. Also note that the problem isn't that
_codegen_ is failing to compile, but that Diesel as a dependency of codegen
is failing

On Mon, Feb 1, 2016 at 12:37 PM Cameron Alexander notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Just did a sanity check, and the version really is 3.8, so maybe the
> codegen is compatible with 3.7.15, but not 3.7.9 nor 3.8?
> 
> 窶能n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/sgrif/diesel/issues/167#issuecomment-178145252.

...And I just realized what the problem is.

On Mon, Feb 1, 2016 at 12:38 PM Sean Griffin sean@seantheprogrammer.com
wrote:

> It's definitely compatible with 3.8. If you look at the failure message
> appearing on Travis, it's due to `sqlite3_errstr` not being found, which
> means it's an ancient 3.7 version. Also note that the problem isn't that
> _codegen_ is failing to compile, but that Diesel as a dependency of codegen
> is failing
> 
> On Mon, Feb 1, 2016 at 12:37 PM Cameron Alexander <
> notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> > Just did a sanity check, and the version really is 3.8, so maybe the
> > codegen is compatible with 3.7.15, but not 3.7.9 nor 3.8?
> > 
> > 窶能n> > Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> > https://github.com/sgrif/diesel/issues/167#issuecomment-178145252.

Wait, never mind, I don't actually know what the problem is. I thought it
might have something to do with
https://github.com/sgrif/diesel/blob/master/diesel_codegen/Cargo.toml#L20,
but we override that in the cargo config to use the local path, and there's
no reason that the error it'd cause would be related to an old version of
SQLite.

On Mon, Feb 1, 2016 at 12:39 PM Sean Griffin sean@seantheprogrammer.com
wrote:

>

Ah, I see that now. The error I was getting original had something to do with lifetimes, but I think that was unrelated.

issue.title: remove usage of sqlite3_errstr

repository.name: diesel
repository.description: A safe, extensible ORM and Query Builder for Rust

issue.body:
I'm stuck with an older version of sqlite (3.6). It appears that the only newer feature actually used is `sqlite3_errstr` in `diesel::sqlite::connection::error_message`.

`libsqlite3-sys` provides a comparable function `libsqlite3-sys::code_to_str` that should be able to be used in place of `sqlite3_errstr`. Would it be possible to switch this out?

I've modified this locally and everything seems to be working great—

This issue also relates to #238 and #167.

Thanks for considering—Diesel looks great!

issue.title: print-schema fails to generate schema for table with foreign key

repository.name: diesel
repository.description: A safe, extensible ORM and Query Builder for Rust

issue.body:
<!--
If you want to report a bug, we added some points below you can fill out. If you want to request a feature, feel free to remove all the irrelevant text. In addition to this [issue tracker](https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/issues), you can also talk to Diesel maintainers and users on [Gitter](https://gitter.im/diesel-rs/diesel).
-->

## Setup

```sql
BEGIN;

CREATE SCHEMA diesel_error

CREATE TABLE diesel_error.foo (
  id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
  date DATE NOT NULL
);

CREATE UNIQUE INDEX foo_id_date ON diesel_error.foo (id, date);

CREATE TABLE diesel_error.bar (
  id SERIAL PRIMARY KEY,
  foo_id INTEGER NOT NULL REFERENCES diesel_error.foo(id),
  date DATE,
  FOREIGN KEY (foo_id, date) REFERENCES diesel_error.foo(id, date)
);

COMMIT;
```

### Versions

- **Rust:** 1.32.0-nightly
- **Diesel:** 1.3.1
- **Database:** PostgreSQL 11.1
- **Operating System** Linux turing 4.4.0-141-generic #167-Ubuntu SMP Wed Dec 5 10:40:15 UTC 2018 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

### Feature Flags

- **diesel:** postgres

## Problem Description

When trying to run `diesel print-schema` for the above schema, diesel prints the following error:

```
Unexpected null for non-null column
```

### What are you trying to accomplish?

I want to use an index that contains a nullable field. I realize that columns in which said field are `null` will not be part of the index, but that is acceptable to me.

### What is the expected output?

A working schema.rs file.

### What is the actual output?

Nothing

### Are you seeing any additional errors?

No.

### Steps to reproduce

Deploy the schema from above, and run `diesel print-schema` on it.

<!--
Please include as much of your codebase as needed to reproduce the error.  If the relevant files are large, please consider linking to a public repository or a [Gist](https://gist.github.com/).

Please post as much of your database schema as necessary. If you are using `infer_schema!`, you can use `diesel print-schema` and post the relevant parts from that.
-->

## Checklist

- [x] I have already looked over the [issue tracker](https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/issues) for similar issues.
- [x] This issue can be reproduced on Rust's stable channel. (Your issue will be
  closed if this is not the case)

This has nothing to do with rust.

<!--
Thank you for your submission!  You're helping make Diesel more robust 沁噂r

We'll try to respond as quickly as possible.
-->
